description: Take n-th prime p, let P = all primes that can be obtained by permuting the digits of p and possibly omitting zeros; a(n) = |p-q| where q in P is the closest to p but different from p (a(n)=0 if no such q exists).
example: a(6)=18 since 6th prime is 13 and 31-13=18. a(25)=90 since 23rd prime is 101 and 101-11=90.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 16 2000
extensions: More terms from Asher Natan Auel (auela(AT)reed.edu), May 12, 2000
